revision.text: {{WPMILHIST|class=Start|Weaponry=yes|British=yes|WWI=yes| |B1=n |B2=y |B3=y |B4=y |B5=y }} ==Segmentation?== I dunno, but I've read somewhere that it doesn't actually help segmentation if its done on the outside, or if its done in grooves outside. [[User:AllStarZ|AllStarZ]] 01:13, 10 March 2007 (UTC) Yeah, even the main hand grenade article notes that the external segmentation doesn't increase fragmentation... [[Special:Contributions/71.185.139.146|71.185.139.146]] ([[User talk:71.185.139.146|talk]]) 12:55, 7 September 2011 (UTC) ==Bowled not thrown== The grenade was not "thrown". It was bowled overarm with a straight arm, like a cricket ball. The disctinction is important if you're using it. [[User:Rcbutcher|Rcbutcher]] ([[User talk:Rcbutcher|talk]]) 05:14, 31 May 2008 (UTC) :I bet that somewhere, sometime, one of the suckers was thrown.[[Special:Contributions/172.190.46.133|172.190.46.133]] ([[User talk:172.190.46.133|talk]]) 02:28, 30 June 2011 (UTC) ::Not only that, me, but bowling implies that the object in question is sent rolling along the ground, something quite inadvisable with regard to grenades.--[[Special:Contributions/172.190.185.26|172.190.185.26]] ([[User talk:172.190.185.26|talk]]) 03:59, 1 March 2012 (UTC) ==Discrepancy between dates?== The "stats" sidebar at right says used from 1915-1970's, but the last paragraph it says MANUFACTURED into the early 1980's: is there supposed to be a difference? ==Throwing Range== Article says that it could be thrown 30 yards. The entry for the German Model 24 Grenade (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Model_24_grenade) says that the Mills would only be thrown 15 yards, where the 24 would go 30-40, therefore Germany made the design decision for a heavier grenade. —Preceding [[Wikipedia:Signatures|unsigned]] comment added by [[Special:Contributions/74.95.162.137|74.95.162.137]] ([[User talk:74.95.162.137|talk]]) 14:14, 15 March 2010 (UTC) --[[Special:Contributions/24.57.225.36|24.57.225.36]] ([[User talk:24.57.225.36|talk]]) 00:54, 2 March 2009 (UTC) :Fifteen yards? Yet another danger associated with the playing of soccer: an inability to throw grenades very far. Even thirty sounds low to me, but we Americans learn to throw things from an early age. Hit my mother in the eye with a block when I was still in a crib. In all seriousness, though, any figure for grenade throwing range is bound to be arbitrary in the extreme, possibly to the point of it not being suitably verifiable for an encyclopedia.--[[Special:Contributions/172.190.185.26|172.190.185.26]] ([[User talk:172.190.185.26|talk]]) 05:11, 1 March 2012 (UTC) Any British kid learns to throw at an early age too, it's cute that you were so excited to feel superior though. 15 yards is obvious bullshit, my granny could throw further. — Preceding [[Wikipedia:Signatures|unsigned]] comment added by [[Special:Contributions/82.9.182.125|82.9.182.125]] ([[User talk:82.9.182.125|talk]]) 15:57, 1 January 2013 (UTC) ::[http://met.open.ac.uk/group/jwl/hg_manual/25.htm Home Guard Pocket manual] says 30yds. And we can assume the British Army had the measure of their troops. The British summer sport is cricket which means the average British schoolboy of the time could both both kick and throw things.30 yards sounds good for something that weighs nearly 2lb. Basic thing to remember with Mills bomb is that lethal range > throwing range.[[User:GraemeLeggett|GraemeLeggett]] ([[User talk:GraemeLeggett|talk]]) 12:45, 1 March 2012 (UTC) == External links modified == Hello fellow Wikipedians, I have just added archive links to {{plural:2|one external link|2 external links}} on [[Mills bomb]].
